results.headline: Stoned Archive: Wild Ride Of the Merry Pranksters
results.display_title: Magic Trip: Ken Kesey's Search for a Kool Place

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Magic Trip: Ken Kesey's Search for a Kool Place

results.summary_short: Alex Gibney and Alison Ellwood’s documentary “Magic Trip” chronicles the 1964 acid-fueled cross-country bus journey of the author Ken Kesey and his friends.

results.headline: To the Victors, Vengeance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Habermann

results.summary_short: “Habermann,” by Juraj Herz, is a wartime soap opera based on the expulsion of ethnic Germans from parts of Europe.

results.headline: A Different Kind of Bronx Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gun Hill Road

results.summary_short: In “Gun Hill Road,” a father comes home to the Bronx from prison to find his son saving up for sexual reassignment surgery.

results.headline: A Study of Time, Love and Decay in Genoa

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Mouth of the Wolf

results.summary_short: Pietro Marcello’s documentary “The Mouth of the Wolf,” filmed in Genoa, Italy, tells the story of a man and his transsexual partner who fell in love while they were in prison.

results.headline: Children in the Fields, but Not at Play

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Harvest

results.summary_short: “The Harvest/La Cosecha,” a documentary by U. Roberto Romano, tracks three child migrant farmworkers and the grinding cycle of their seasons.

results.headline: Confronting a Plague of Violence

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Interrupters

results.summary_short: “The Interrupters,” a documentary by Steve James, takes a look at a gutsy, activist component of the Chicago Project for Violence Prevention.

results.headline: Is That All There Is? Milking Life for More

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Future

results.summary_short: The fears and frustrations that shadow us on our awkward trip through the life cycle often feel enormous, and “The Future” elevates them to something metaphysical and wondrous.

results.headline: Great Outdoors Beckons as a Test of Manhood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of True Adolescents

results.summary_short: Mark Duplass stars in Craig Johnson’s film “True Adolescents,” which explores the sexual discomfort of boys and men not entirely secure in their masculinity.

results.headline: Inner City vs. Outer Space

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Attack the Block

results.summary_short: Joe Cornish’s comedic “Attack the Block” considers the chance of an alien invasion in South London.

results.headline: Blue Travelers in the Big City

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Smurfs

results.summary_short: “The Smurfs” mixes animation and actors, including Neil Patrick Harris and Hank Azaria, to give characters from the 1980s TV show a New York adventure.

results.headline: Mismatched Partners in a Crime Comedy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Guard

results.summary_short: In “The Guard” Brendan Gleeson and Don Cheadle are reluctant crime-fighting buddies.

results.headline: Straight From Uday Hussein’s Inner Circle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Devil's Double

results.summary_short: “The Devil’s Double,” a slick, English-language excursion into Saddam Hussein’s Iraq, might seem either timely or insensitive, given the uprisings in the Middle East.

results.headline: The Slow Life in Trefeurig

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sleep Furiously

results.summary_short: “Sleep Furiously,” Gideon Koppel’s documentary, tracks how time passes in a Welsh farming community.

results.headline: It’s Paris, and Everyone Is Rotten but the Man Chased by the Police

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Point Blank

results.summary_short: “Point Blank” is a French thriller involving cops, gangsters, a kidnapping and a breakneck chase.

results.headline: The World as YouTube Knows It

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life in a Day

results.summary_short: “Life in a Day” draws on more than 80,000 submissions to edit a video-clip mozaic of the planet.

results.headline: Gay in Amsterdam in the 1980s

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of House of Boys

results.summary_short: In “House of Boys” the director Jean-Claude Schlim looks at coming of age at the onset of AIDS.

results.headline: The Local Serial Killer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Good Neighbors

results.summary_short: “Good Neighbors,” directed by Jacob Tierney, tells of three Montreal residents and the murder case they must solve.

results.headline: Fellowship of the Links

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Golf in the Kingdom

results.summary_short: “Golf in the Kingdom,” directed by Susan Streitfeld, brings the cult novel by Michael Murphy to the screen.

results.headline: What’s a Guy to Do if His Wife Cheats on Him? Head to the Mall

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crazy, Stupid, Love

results.summary_short: “Crazy, Stupid, Love,” packed with appealing stars, is essentially a study in the varieties of masculine sexual confusion.

results.headline: Extraterrestrials Land at the O.K. Corral

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cowboys & Aliens

results.summary_short: In “Cowboys & Aliens,” Daniel Craig rides into the New Mexico Territory and wrangles extraterrestrials that look like cousins of the monsters from the “Alien” films.
